Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Circumferential Patellar Cauterization in Bilateral TKA

Trial_Design.evidence: This prospective, quasi-randomized trial included 78 patients (156 knees) undergoing bilateral, simultaneous TKA without patellar resurfacing.

Participants.evidence: This prospective, quasi-randomized trial included 78 patients (156 knees) undergoing bilateral, simultaneous TKA without patellar resurfacing.

Intervention.evidence: Each patient served as their own control, with patellar cauterization performed on the right knee.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether circumferential patellar cauterization reduces anterior knee pain and enhances functional outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Kujala score for anterior knee pain, measured preoperatively and at 1 month and 2 years postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was based on laterality, and no blinding was applied.

Blinding.evidence: Randomization was based on laterality, and no blinding was applied.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This prospective, quasi-randomized trial included 78 patients (156 knees) undergoing bilateral, simultaneous TKA without patellar resurfacing.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At the 2-year follow-up, no significant difference was observed in the Kujala score between cauterized and non-cauterized knees (mean difference 0.3; 95% CI, -0.599 to 1.202; p = 0.509).

Harms.evidence: Complication rates were low and similar, with one deep venous thromboembolism in the cauterized group and two in the control group (odds ratio 0.49, 95% CI, 0.04-5.56; p = 0.57).

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding information were not disclosed.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding information were not disclosed.
